data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div class="mck-u-links-inline">Healthcare organizations can use M&A to drive strategic goals while securing long-term value.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<p>As we emerge from the COVID-19 crisis, healthcare organizations need to align on and begin implementing their strategic and operational plans for the post-pandemic era, including responding to the potential disruption of traditional business models. The <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-great-acceleration-in-healthcare-six-trends-to-heed">trends that have been shaping the healthcare industry</a>, such as consumer adoption of digital health platforms and tools, will likely accelerate in the wake of COVID-19. We anticipate the crisis will impact growth rates across healthcare segments, specifically increasing growth for healthcare services companies (especially in virtual care platforms including telehealth, patient engagement, and wearable technologies) while payers’ and providers’ traditional core businesses may see declining earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) growth.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="123d4092-ad6f-4519-be96-bf6e4f2ed39b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="123d4092-ad6f-4519-be96-bf6e4f2ed39b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Healthcare Profit Pools Model.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>As healthcare organizations look to evolve their business models, we are seeing increasing M&A activity among those seeking to add scale as well as diversify through new capabilities and services. Healthcare deal volume in Q4 2020 was 21 percent higher than in Q4 2019.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ce5458da-5dbb-4bdb-a4cf-2b57efabcccd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ce5458da-5dbb-4bdb-a4cf-2b57efabcccd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“H2C Industry Insights 2020 in Review: Healthcare M&A Transactions Database,” Hammond Hanlon Camp, January 19, 2021, h2c.com.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition, in our survey of more than 700 organizations, a third anticipated more M&A activity post-pandemic than planned prior to the crisis.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e0b3d97a-8a87-41eb-b1e3-0c9c42688990"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e0b3d97a-8a87-41eb-b1e3-0c9c42688990" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey M&A Capabilities Survey 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>However, as our research and experience working with healthcare organizations has found, not all M&A strategies are equally likely to prove accretive. In this article, we share how healthcare organizations can best use M&A to drive their strategic goals while ensuring long-term value creation.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/healthcare/how-we-help-clients">Healthcare Systems & Services Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header></div></div></div>
<h2>Types of M&A players</h2>
<p>For the past decade, we have been conducting <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/repeat-performance-the-continuing-case-for-programmatic-m-and-a">M&A research on the top global companies</a> by market capitalization to understand what drives value creation. In this research, we identify four types of M&A activity for organizations across industries:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Programmatic: More than two small/midsize deals per year</li>
    <li>Large deals: One or more deals where target market capitalization was more than 30 percent of acquirer’s market capitalization and/or revenue</li>
    <li>Selective: Less than two small/midsize deals per year</li>
    <li>Organic: Less than one small deal every three years</li>
</ul>
<p>Our latest refresh of this M&A research, which expanded the cross-sector company universe from the Global 1000 to the Global 2000 and shifted the time window forward through 2019, affirmed our previous findings that programmatic acquirers were more likely to outperform other M&A types (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/healthcares%20evolving%20chessboard/svg-hss-mna-exhibit4-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Across industries, programmatic strategies generate highest total shareholder returns with lowest risk." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/healthcares%20evolving%20chessboard/svg-hss-mna-exhibit4-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Across all industries, programmatic acquirers achieved higher excess total returns to shareholders (TSR) than industry peers, with the least amount of risk as measured by standard deviation. Both selective and organic M&A approaches most often resulted in negative TSR; results for large deal acquirers were neutral on average, with some organizations driving outsized returns compared with their peers and others losing value post-acquisition.</p>
<p>The same findings also hold true for healthcare companies in the Global 2000 (Exhibit 2). Large, public healthcare companies adopting programmatic M&A delivered the highest average excess TSR compared with other M&A types, and large deals carried the greatest risk. These implications apply to non-public and nonprofit organizations as well, given that programmatic M&A strategy, capabilities, and processes are consistent across organizations, and these organizations compete with the large, public companies with respect to M&A targets. Importantly, a diversity of approaches remains; some healthcare players continue to pursue M&A to consolidate, especially via large deals, while others are pursuing diversified business building, often enabled by programmatic M&A. We expect additional players to pivot toward growth-driven M&A as we emerge from the pandemic.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/healthcares%20evolving%20chessboard/svg-hss-mna-exhibit1-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Healthcare companies that executed programmatic M&A strategies tend to drive consistent returns above peers--and large deals carried the most risk." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/healthcares%20evolving%20chessboard/svg-hss-mna-exhibit1-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Programmatic M&A is not just about executing on serial acquisitions; rather, programmatic acquirers execute a series of choreographed deals around specific themes, such as building new diversified businesses or acquiring new capabilities. Programmatic M&A is a strategic, proactive, and disciplined approach to creating deal flow, resulting in a series of related transactions that support a clear M&A blueprint that is linked to corporate strategy. Healthcare players can use programmatic M&A to help pivot their organizations coming out of the pandemic. For example, one large US health system previously pursued hospital acquisitions to complement its regional market footprint, yet in the last two years has pivoted to focus on acquisitions in growing areas of healthcare that complement its core acute care service offerings. This shift in strategy has included deals focused on home health and managing total cost of care with technologies that address alternative payment models (for example, bundled payments). Similarly, one company that provides services and supplies to office-based healthcare providers has leveraged M&A to increase its geographic scale globally, broaden the supplies it distributes, and diversify its offerings to include technology solutions. Since the pandemic began, this organization has also used M&A to enter home healthcare and wound care as new verticals adjacent to its core.</p>
<h2>Value creation in large deals</h2>
<p>Our research shows that large deals are “big bets” that could lead to big wins or, just as easily, to big losses. We looked at value creation from the universe of large deals completed by the Global 2000 since 2010 for which we had at least five years of post-close data. We found that their value creation is hard to predict and driven largely by execution over approximately two years. Deals that showed TSR after two years were also likely to show excess TSR after five years (Exhibit 3).</p>

<p>With programmatic M&A, smaller organizations are largely incorporated into the acquiring organization as part of the broader corporate strategy, or as a new business unit. In contrast, larger mergers tend to face more significant cultural issues, as well as more functions and processes that need to be merged and regulatory requirements. These issues increase the number and scale of integration hurdles and, for healthcare companies, the risk of disruption to patient care or experience.</p>
<p>Given this inherent challenge, healthcare organizations, when considering these transformational events, may factor in three lessons learned to mitigate risk and increase their chances of success:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Bet carefully: Making a large, horizontal deal in an evolving sector like healthcare can be risky. Companies may need to change industry dynamics to avoid underperformance</li>
    <li>Be wary of distraction to patient care or experience: Large deals tend to perform best in mature organizations with established offerings, a loyal patient base, and stable relationships with other players and vendors</li>
    <li>Be realistic about the ability to execute: Few healthcare companies have real experience in executing large-scale integrations and run the risk of underestimating the investment of time and resources successful integrations require</li>
</ul>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="The future of healthcare: Value creation through next-generation business models" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20future%20of%20healthcare%20value%20creation/standard-future-healthcare-697564199.png?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>The future of healthcare: Value creation through next-generation business models</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-future-of-healthcare-value-creation-through-next-generation-business-models" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h2>Capabilities that drive M&A success</h2>
<p>Healthcare organizations can unlock value in M&A and can improve their odds for success by adopting specific <a href="/capabilities/m-and-a/our-insights/practice-makes-perfect-what-sets-programmatic-acquirers-apart">best practices across the end-to-end deal process</a>. These include:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>M&A blueprint:</em> A clearly articulated <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/a-blueprint-for-m-and-a-success">M&A blueprint</a> addresses how, why, and where organizations will use M&A to achieve their corporate strategy. A blueprint drives success across the deal process by forcing difficult conversations and internal alignment within the leadership team early, well before any specific target gains momentum. A blueprint can help address the questions we hear often from our healthcare clients, such as “What should our goal for total revenue by 2030 be, and how should we get there? Would we do one larger merger, smaller ones, or try to build it ourselves?”</li>
    <li><em>Proactive deal sourcing:</em> Build a dynamic asset pipeline by actively identifying and monitoring potential candidates across the market landscape, independent of which assets are currently “for sale.” Organizations may leverage both internal functions and external networks to source potential opportunities</li>
    <li><em>Strategic and tailored target cultivation:</em> Strong acquirers engage potential targets early and often, and continually update their pitch as they learn more about target organizations. They orient their focus around targets with a shared vision for the future and causes for action common to both parties</li>
    <li><em>Comprehensive due diligence:</em> Place as much emphasis on strategic and cultural due diligence as on financial, legal, and tax due diligence</li>
    <li><em>Playbooks and learning:</em> Document end-to-end processes in an M&A playbook that is tailored and leveraged for each deal. Organizations should also aim to continuously learn and update their playbooks with lessons from completed deals</li>
</ul>

data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Why these capabilities matter for healthcare players:</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><ul>
    <li>In recent years, several healthcare stakeholders have pursued vertical integration to create <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-next-wave-of-healthcare-innovation-the-evolution-of-ecosystems">healthcare ecosystems</a> (sets of capabilities and services that integrate value chain participants to improve stakeholder experience and reduce inefficiencies), a trend which we expect to continue. An M&A blueprint can help guide organizations looking to participate in ecosystems by informing decisions about where to acquire new offerings or pursue partnerships.</li>
    <li>Many not-for-profit healthcare organizations have seen favorable investment returns over the last decade, which have strengthened balance sheets. Not-for-profit health systems, for instance, reported higher median days cash on hand before the pandemic than during the prior decade. As these organizations aim to diversify in an environment that has also seen rising valuations for healthcare targets, strategic sourcing will be critical to identify the right assets to pursue, aligned to a long-term corporate strategy.</li>
    <li>Target cultivation can look different given the preponderance of nonprofit healthcare organizations, which may prioritize partnership considerations differently than for-profit companies. Many nonprofits have not pursued large deals or programmatic M&A previously, which further underscores the importance of developing these capabilities.</li>
    <li>Programmatic M&A can help healthcare organizations in segments with limited growth (including limited growth potential for their core service offering in their geography) to pursue diversification and add capabilities that will be needed for <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-future-of-healthcare-value-creation-through-next-generation-business-models">next-generation business models</a>. Areas of potential interest could include investments across the pre-acute and post-acute continuum, as well as value-based care assets. Importantly, our research has shown that health systems pursuing diversified business models that encompass a greater range of care delivery assets are generating returns above expectations.<sup>1</sup></li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>We surveyed more than 700 companies on their M&A activities and found that programmatic acquirers were most likely to demonstrate these best practices and capabilities, compared with companies that executed other types of M&A strategies (Exhibit 4). Importantly, while many of these practices may be well understood, less than half of respondents, even among programmatic acquirers, felt their organizations adhered to the activities described above.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/healthcares%20evolving%20chessboard/svg-hss-mna-exhibit3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Our M&A survey results: Programmatic acquirers more closely adhere to best practices in deal sourcing, cultivation, and execution." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/healthcares%20evolving%20chessboard/svg-hss-mna-exhibit3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>M&A can be an important lever for healthcare organizations to shape and innovate their offerings in the face of industry headwinds. As we enter the ‘next normal,’ organizations with the capabilities to diversify and grow via M&A may be best positioned to thrive, thereby benefiting their employees, patients, and local communities.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><a href="/our-people/edward-levine"><strong>Edward Levine, MD</strong></a>, is a senior partner in McKinsey’s Silicon Valley office, <a href="/our-people/neil-rao"><strong>Neil Rao</strong></a> is a partner in the Seattle office, <strong>Robert Uhlaner</strong> is a senior partner in the San Francisco office, and <a href="/our-people/liz-wol"><strong>Liz Wol</strong></a> is a partner in the New Jersey office.</p>

<p>The authors wish to thank Caitlin Sengelaub, Riccardo Andreola, Jack Gordon, and Jason Azzoparde for their contributions to this article.</p>

<p>This article was edited by Elizabeth Newman, an executive editor in the Chicago office.</p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-screen-only"><div id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Healthcares evolving chessboard M and A capabilities to accelerate long term strategy","displayName":"Healthcares evolving chessboard M and A capabilities to accelerate long term strategy","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"3846d659-8103-441f-84b5-27f533c454a6","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":2,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Healthcare\u0026rsquo;s evolving chessboard: M\u0026amp;A capabilities to accelerate long-term strategy"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"M\u0026amp;As accelerate long-term healthcare strategy"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Healthcare organizations can use M\u0026amp;A to drive strategic goals while securing long-term value."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-06-24T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eAs we emerge from the COVID-19 crisis, healthcare organizations need to align on and begin implementing their strategic and operational plans for the post-pandemic era, including responding to the potential disruption of traditional business models. The \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-great-acceleration-in-healthcare-six-trends-to-heed\"\u003etrends that have been shaping the healthcare industry\u003c/a\u003e, such as consumer adoption of digital health platforms and tools, will likely accelerate in the wake of COVID-19. We anticipate the crisis will impact growth rates across healthcare segments, specifically increasing growth for healthcare services companies (especially in virtual care platforms including telehealth, patient engagement, and wearable technologies) while payers\u0026rsquo; and providers\u0026rsquo; traditional core businesses may see declining earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) growth.[[footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs healthcare organizations look to evolve their business models, we are seeing increasing M\u0026amp;A activity among those seeking to add scale as well as diversify through new capabilities and services. Healthcare deal volume in Q4 2020 was 21 percent higher than in Q4 2019.[[footnote 2]] In addition, in our survey of more than 700 organizations, a third anticipated more M\u0026amp;A activity post-pandemic than planned prior to the crisis.[[footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, as our research and experience working with healthcare organizations has found, not all M\u0026amp;A strategies are equally likely to prove accretive. In this article, we share how healthcare organizations can best use M\u0026amp;A to drive their strategic goals while ensuring long-term value creation.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up learnmore]]\n\u003ch2\u003eTypes of M\u0026amp;A players\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor the past decade, we have been conducting \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/repeat-performance-the-continuing-case-for-programmatic-m-and-a\"\u003eM\u0026amp;A research on the top global companies\u003c/a\u003e by market capitalization to understand what drives value creation. In this research, we identify four types of M\u0026amp;A activity for organizations across industries:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eProgrammatic: More than two small/midsize deals per year\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eLarge deals: One or more deals where target market capitalization was more than 30 percent of acquirer\u0026rsquo;s market capitalization and/or revenue\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSelective: Less than two small/midsize deals per year\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOrganic: Less than one small deal every three years\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur latest refresh of this M\u0026amp;A research, which expanded the cross-sector company universe from the Global 1000 to the Global 2000 and shifted the time window forward through 2019, affirmed our previous findings that programmatic acquirers were more likely to outperform other M\u0026amp;A types (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eAcross all industries, programmatic acquirers achieved higher excess total returns to shareholders (TSR) than industry peers, with the least amount of risk as measured by standard deviation. Both selective and organic M\u0026amp;A approaches most often resulted in negative TSR; results for large deal acquirers were neutral on average, with some organizations driving outsized returns compared with their peers and others losing value post-acquisition.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe same findings also hold true for healthcare companies in the Global 2000 (Exhibit 2). Large, public healthcare companies adopting programmatic M\u0026amp;A delivered the highest average excess TSR compared with other M\u0026amp;A types, and large deals carried the greatest risk. These implications apply to non-public and nonprofit organizations as well, given that programmatic M\u0026amp;A strategy, capabilities, and processes are consistent across organizations, and these organizations compete with the large, public companies with respect to M\u0026amp;A targets. Importantly, a diversity of approaches remains; some healthcare players continue to pursue M\u0026amp;A to consolidate, especially via large deals, while others are pursuing diversified business building, often enabled by programmatic M\u0026amp;A. We expect additional players to pivot toward growth-driven M\u0026amp;A as we emerge from the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eProgrammatic M\u0026amp;A is not just about executing on serial acquisitions; rather, programmatic acquirers execute a series of choreographed deals around specific themes, such as building new diversified businesses or acquiring new capabilities. Programmatic M\u0026amp;A is a strategic, proactive, and disciplined approach to creating deal flow, resulting in a series of related transactions that support a clear M\u0026amp;A blueprint that is linked to corporate strategy. Healthcare players can use programmatic M\u0026amp;A to help pivot their organizations coming out of the pandemic. For example, one large US health system previously pursued hospital acquisitions to complement its regional market footprint, yet in the last two years has pivoted to focus on acquisitions in growing areas of healthcare that complement its core acute care service offerings. This shift in strategy has included deals focused on home health and managing total cost of care with technologies that address alternative payment models (for example, bundled payments). Similarly, one company that provides services and supplies to office-based healthcare providers has leveraged M\u0026amp;A to increase its geographic scale globally, broaden the supplies it distributes, and diversify its offerings to include technology solutions. Since the pandemic began, this organization has also used M\u0026amp;A to enter home healthcare and wound care as new verticals adjacent to its core.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eValue creation in large deals\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur research shows that large deals are \u0026ldquo;big bets\u0026rdquo; that could lead to big wins or, just as easily, to big losses. We looked at value creation from the universe of large deals completed by the Global 2000 since 2010 for which we had at least five years of post-close data. We found that their value creation is hard to predict and driven largely by execution over approximately two years. Deals that showed TSR after two years were also likely to show excess TSR after five years (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibitcarousel 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eWith programmatic M\u0026amp;A, smaller organizations are largely incorporated into the acquiring organization as part of the broader corporate strategy, or as a new business unit. In contrast, larger mergers tend to face more significant cultural issues, as well as more functions and processes that need to be merged and regulatory requirements. These issues increase the number and scale of integration hurdles and, for healthcare companies, the risk of disruption to patient care or experience.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven this inherent challenge, healthcare organizations, when considering these transformational events, may factor in three lessons learned to mitigate risk and increase their chances of success:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBet carefully: Making a large, horizontal deal in an evolving sector like healthcare can be risky. Companies may need to change industry dynamics to avoid underperformance\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBe wary of distraction to patient care or experience: Large deals tend to perform best in mature organizations with established offerings, a loyal patient base, and stable relationships with other players and vendors\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBe realistic about the ability to execute: Few healthcare companies have real experience in executing large-scale integrations and run the risk of underestimating the investment of time and resources successful integrations require\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[disruptor1up readnext]]\n\u003ch2\u003eCapabilities that drive M\u0026amp;A success\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHealthcare organizations can unlock value in M\u0026amp;A and can improve their odds for success by adopting specific \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/m-and-a/our-insights/practice-makes-perfect-what-sets-programmatic-acquirers-apart\"\u003ebest practices across the end-to-end deal process\u003c/a\u003e. These include:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eM\u0026amp;A blueprint:\u003c/em\u003e A clearly articulated \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/a-blueprint-for-m-and-a-success\"\u003eM\u0026amp;A blueprint\u003c/a\u003e addresses how, why, and where organizations will use M\u0026amp;A to achieve their corporate strategy. A blueprint drives success across the deal process by forcing difficult conversations and internal alignment within the leadership team early, well before any specific target gains momentum. A blueprint can help address the questions we hear often from our healthcare clients, such as \u0026ldquo;What should our goal for total revenue by 2030 be, and how should we get there? Would we do one larger merger, smaller ones, or try to build it ourselves?\u0026rdquo;\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eProactive deal sourcing:\u003c/em\u003e Build a dynamic asset pipeline by actively identifying and monitoring potential candidates across the market landscape, independent of which assets are currently \u0026ldquo;for sale.\u0026rdquo; Organizations may leverage both internal functions and external networks to source potential opportunities\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eStrategic and tailored target cultivation:\u003c/em\u003e Strong acquirers engage potential targets early and often, and continually update their pitch as they learn more about target organizations. They orient their focus around targets with a shared vision for the future and causes for action common to both parties\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eComprehensive due diligence:\u003c/em\u003e Place as much emphasis on strategic and cultural due diligence as on financial, legal, and tax due diligence\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePlaybooks and learning:\u003c/em\u003e Document end-to-end processes in an M\u0026amp;A playbook that is tailored and leveraged for each deal. Organizations should also aim to continuously learn and update their playbooks with lessons from completed deals\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eWe surveyed more than 700 companies on their M\u0026amp;A activities and found that programmatic acquirers were most likely to demonstrate these best practices and capabilities, compared with companies that executed other types of M\u0026amp;A strategies (Exhibit 4). Importantly, while many of these practices may be well understood, less than half of respondents, even among programmatic acquirers, felt their organizations adhered to the activities described above.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eM\u0026amp;A can be an important lever for healthcare organizations to shape and innovate their offerings in the face of industry headwinds. As we enter the \u0026lsquo;next normal,\u0026rsquo; organizations with the capabilities to diversify and grow via M\u0026amp;A may be best positioned to thrive, thereby benefiting their employees, patients, and local current on your favorite topics"}}}]},"articlesidebar":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"1"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIn recent years, several healthcare stakeholders have pursued vertical integration to create \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-next-wave-of-healthcare-innovation-the-evolution-of-ecosystems\"\u003ehealthcare ecosystems\u003c/a\u003e (sets of capabilities and services that integrate value chain participants to improve stakeholder experience and reduce inefficiencies), a trend which we expect to continue. An M\u0026amp;A blueprint can help guide organizations looking to participate in ecosystems by informing decisions about where to acquire new offerings or pursue partnerships.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMany not-for-profit healthcare organizations have seen favorable investment returns over the last decade, which have strengthened balance sheets. Not-for-profit health systems, for instance, reported higher median days cash on hand before the pandemic than during the prior decade. As these organizations aim to diversify in an environment that has also seen rising valuations for healthcare targets, strategic sourcing will be critical to identify the right assets to pursue, aligned to a long-term corporate strategy.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eTarget cultivation can look different given the preponderance of nonprofit healthcare organizations, which may prioritize partnership considerations differently than for-profit companies. Many nonprofits have not pursued large deals or programmatic M\u0026amp;A previously, which further underscores the importance of developing these capabilities.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eProgrammatic M\u0026amp;A can help healthcare organizations in segments with limited growth (including limited growth potential for their core service offering in their geography) to pursue diversification and add capabilities that will be needed for \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-future-of-healthcare-value-creation-through-next-generation-business-models\"\u003enext-generation business models\u003c/a\u003e. Areas of potential interest could include investments across the pre-acute and post-acute continuum, as well as value-based care assets. Importantly, our research has shown that health systems pursuing diversified business models that encompass a greater range of care delivery assets are generating returns above
